Reviews.Title: “No hot water - Very rude staff”
Reviews.Author: Tim023
Reviews.Content: After a 30 hour flight from Asia, I arrive to the hotel only to find there is not hot water in the room. After a couple of hours claiming they were going to send someone to my room they finally admit there is no hot water in any room. Another 30-45 minutes later they finally let me use the shower facilities at the hotel spa for "free". Once in the spa, which is managed by the hotel, the attendants treat me as a criminal, tracking my every move, as if I were stealing their valuable services. Overall very poor attitude of the staff. First time at any hotel not in the tropics, where there is no hot water.

Reviews.Title: “Comfortable, perfect stay”
Reviews.Author: SFOAaron
Reviews.Content: I actually found this hotel at the last minute as accommodations for a small group, including four high school students. I was a little bit concerned about the area, which in turn made me apprehensive about the hotel. I was very pleasantly surprised to find my concerns about the area and the hotel completely unwarranted. Let's start with the hotel: Very nicely appointed rooms, very comfortable beds, and very clean. It almost seemed like it was newly remodeled. Bathrooms include heated bidets with very complicated instructions - I didn't even try - but they looked cool. The high school kids were a little confused until I told them they were butt-washers, and then they just nodded and changed the subject. I had street-side windows, and any noise that got through was reasonable for downtown LA in the early evening. Then it got really quiet. In fact the only time noise bothered me at all was when it got so quiet (middle of the night) was a garbage truck beeping - for-ev-ver. (But that's not the hotels fault.) Room (7th floor) had a nice view of the San Bernadino mountains. The rest of the hotel facilities appear minimal - no gym, pool or anything like that. Big plus for free wifi and only $1 for the bottled water. It was refreshing to stay somewhere where I didn't feel like they were trying to turn the last screw. I found wonderfully tawdry bar on the second floor with a karaoke thing going on -obviously full of locals who take Karaoke -very- seriously! They have some sort of spa, but it's not a general use thing. No pool as far as I could tell. Down one star because of the absurdly over-priced breakfast buffet (albeit with some sort of asian flair). It was the only dining choice, and I wasn't quite ready to venture out. I could have used a simple breakfast. Didn't have that choice. The hotel staff was friendly and efficient, however the bar staff could have been a little more attentive. I had a friend meet me for a few drinks, and we had a lot of difficulty getting a second drink even though we were actually sitting AT the bar. The rest of the staff, including the front desk, valet, and concierge, heck even the housekeeper, were very helpful and friendly. (The housekeeper gets an extra ++ for checking with me about the rooms after realizing I was chaperoning kids). OK - the area: Downtown LA, a few blocks from City Hall. Metro station is just a short walk away and it only took 20 minutes or so to ride over to Hollywood to do the tourist thing. The Disney concert hall is within walking distance.There are starbucks coffee bars in every direction, but I'd head south one block and then go west. Seems to be a revitalized area with restaurants, shopping and bars in one of those hip condo live-walk-work communities. The streets were clean, well-lit and safe.

Reviews.Title: “I like Japanese hotels!”
Reviews.Author: CyberEdge
Reviews.Content: The Miyako is a small, friendly & comfrtable hotel in Little Tokyo. If you have business nearby, FYI is a great value option. Also, it's withinwalking distance of the train station and many transit options.I will go back, happily.

Reviews.Title: “Great location, nice clean hotel”
Reviews.Author: Geiszlah
Reviews.Content: This is a great place to stay if you need to be near downtown LA, but don't want to have to pay the insane prices. We stayed here on a Saturday night for $189 for a deluxe room when rooms less than a mile away in "downtown" were going for over $300 a night. And the quality of what we got in terms of size, quietness and ambiance was far better. Situated in the heart of Little Tokyo - an up and coming section of LA - this hotel is about 2 miles from LA Live and Staples Center and about a mile from downtown. It was an $8 cab ride to the heart of downtown. The hotel itself is nice, if a little bit old. We opted for the larger, deluxe room, which had a seating area next to the beds and was also on the top floor of the hotel. It was comfortable, spacious, and very very quiet. Also, there are a bunch of great Japanese restaurants right across the street so you'll eat well while you're there too. A note of warning - do not walk more than 2-3 blocks in either direction of the hotel. While that area is very nice (and right by the LAPD headquarters), it gets super sketchy really fast. So, even though downtown is less than a mile away, cab it.

Reviews.Title: “A gem in crazy Los Angeles”
Reviews.Author: arachne
Reviews.Content: This was our second round of visits to the Miyako Hotel in Japan Town, staying one night after arriving on the south-bound Coast Starlight Amtrak train, which arrives around 9 or 10 PM--we got in twenty minutes early, again! This time, we rented a car(the Sakura rental agency is just around the corner in the Kyoto Grand Hotel lobby), drove it out to the Salton Sea area to see my mother, drove back to LA, spent two more nights at the Miyako before heading back north on the Coast Starlight at 10:20 AM--very civilized way to travel. Since we had the car, we got to go to LACMA and the Page Museum at the La Brea Tar Pits, which were excellent. Weather was warm and sunny So Cal, nice break in early March. Miyako is everything I expect a good hotel to be--quiet, clean, comfortable, and affordable(with warmed toilet seats and bidets)!) The hotel also has a fantastic spa on site, with various pools of warm to hot water, a sauna and steambath, and skilled massage therapists offering a variety of massages. I happily went for the shiatsu again--Ahhh. Spa rates are very reasonable. The hotel caters to Japanese guests, has great room service Japanese food, and is centrally located in an area full of restaurants. And don't miss the Japanese Internment Museum, just across the street.

Reviews.Title: “Nice downtown hotel with Japanese influences”
Reviews.Author: mjb1001
Reviews.Content: Stayed here for 4 nights in February 2012. Access was easy using public transport, 1 block from the Gold line Japantown station or 4 blocks from Civic Centre Red line. Area seemed safe in the evening with a reasonable selection of restaurants. Rooms are a reasonable size with very comfortable beds and clean bathrooms. Flat screen TV seemed huge. It was also good for getting some work done - connection to WLAN was easy (get the passcode at reception when you check in). Staff were helpful and friendly. They speak at least English, Spanish and Japanese well. The downstairs coffee bar is OK, but the area has a selection of restaurants also, including Japanese, Korean and Mexican. The hotel bar is OK (sit at the bar to avoid the 'karaoke' seating charge). There's a supermarket specializing in Japanese things in Japantown about 3 minutes walk away. Convenient for the Japanese-American National Museum and other downtown attractions, plus Union station 1 stop away by Gold line. An excellent downtown option.

Reviews.Title: “A GEM of a hotel...!”
Reviews.Author: Chris2421356707655
Reviews.Content: There is no better place to stay if you need to be handy for LA Union Station. The rooms are spacious, and the excellent service from the nice lady in the breakfast room is a GREAT start to the day...! I can highly recommend this hotel...!

Reviews.Title: “if you're an LA "expat", it's the better choice in a cooler area”
Reviews.Author: toasty24
Reviews.Content: I'm a New Yorker, originally from LA and had to come back for a wedding. My hotel needed to be in LA proper/central: my choice was Miyako or a hotel near the LA Live area (very touristy). Miyako may be in need of a renovation, but it's clean and reasonably priced, and most importantly, but it's in an up-and-coming, revitalized, and hipsterized Little Tokyo area. This is vital b/c there are times when you don't want to drive and just need a quick break or bite in the local surroundings. When i grew up, LT was dilapidated, almost ghetto-like. now it's teeming with cool boutiques, bars, delicious food, and is just a vibrant, cool place to hang out, everything within walking distance, and should eventually turn into more of a walking/strolling area without being a spectacle like Citywalk, etc. besides Japanese food, there is a german currywurst bierhaus, senor fish tacos, falafel, yogurt shops, etc.. everything within a block or two of Miyako. If you're new to LA, you may not appreciate this hotel's location. But if you are a frequent visitor looking for something more charming, cool, under-the-radar yet still in-the-know, this hotel offers you a clean room, good service, and awesome location. It's also still central to everything else in LA with a quick drive. I didn't have a car while i stayed here, and i was STILL able to enjoy the neighborhood. Highly recommended, no qualms about the room or service at all. Would surely stay there again.

Reviews.Title: “Hotel was Okay”
Reviews.Author: MissLady71
Reviews.Content: I stayed 3nights at this hotel. The lobby was being renovating, and also the gym.The staff was very friendly...I was upset with the cable channel line up..Not enough channels for me...The spa/sauna rooms looked very peaceful. Unfortunately I did not have time for a massage. I suggest to pay extra for the 24hr valet service. Hotel is in little Tokyo, there are plenty of Japanese/Korean restaurants to choose from. My room was basic, I loved the toilet & the bed was extremely comfy......The view of LA skyline was beautiful. The LARGE WINDOW OPENS!!!!!!!! (no sceen, no bars))This is very important, especially if traveling with children.Make sure it's locked.... I did not eat at restaurant, but I bought breakfast at the lobby cafe. I do not think I would stay again.

Reviews.Title: “Wish I was there now!”
Reviews.Author: USJapan
Reviews.Content: Location, Location, Location! Right in the heart of the only place I like in all of Los Angeles, Little Tokyo! The Miyako is affordable by L.A. standards and is clean, comfortable & more than convenient if you're there to enjoy the most authentic slice of Japan outside of Tokyo. Give yourself a real treat and stay New Year's Eve and New Year's Day. NYE is a ghost town but NYD is full of excitement with a traditional Japanese Taiko concert, colorful costumes and lots of good cheer :)

Reviews.Title: “Great location for access to Gold Line Light Rail, but . . .”
Reviews.Author: KCosta
Reviews.Content: The executive King room was adequate, but this suite was very small. Upon arrival, I called the front desk to inquire about upgrading to a larger room and was informed that we were in their largest suite. The sitting chair was crammed between the bed and the window wall. The room was clean and the bathroom was better than average. It had decent aesthetics, but it was not upscale in any way. I appreciated the large flat screen TV. The room had a small refrigerator, coffee maker and safe. We had breakfast at the Kyoto Grand Hotel, which was about a block away. Wished we had stayed their instead, as it was a larger property with the upscale amenities that I was hoping for. The Miyako LA seemed geared for buisness travel.

Reviews.Title: “Always Pleasing”
Reviews.Author: bksgrrrl
Reviews.Content: This was our third stay at the Miyako, and the hotel and staff continue to offer a pleasant experience. We originally chose Miyako because it's close to Union Station, but we continue to return because it's comfortable, very clean, and the staff is outstanding. Everyone at the hotel is friendly and helpful, the neighborhood offers many excellent restaurants and interesting shops, and the location, just off downtown Los Angeles (yes, LA does have a downtown), is convenient to almost everything via light rail Metro. We have yet to try the hotel's breakfast buffet, but the "Take 5" cafe in the lobby offers a fine continental breakfast with yogurt and delicious croissants. a great place to people watch and plan your day.

Reviews.Title: “Fine hotel in Little Tokoyo, Los Angeles”
Reviews.Author: Iris4quilts
Reviews.Content: If you are looking for a hotel close to Union Station, this is a good choice. Staff was friendly. The room looked exactly like the picture online! Remarkable! Very posh and comfortable. Large bathroom with plenty of complimentary mini-toiletries. The breakfast buffet wasn't great, but edible. I didn't take advantage of the free breakfast in the lobby. And my room window opened so I had fresh air.

Reviews.Title: “Excellent hotel surrounded by good eating options”
Reviews.Author: Jeffrey08
Reviews.Content: We found the hotel easily accessible by public transport from the airport. We took the Flyaway bus from LAX to Union Station, followed by a one-stop journery via the Metro Gold line. Stayed for four nights. Room was clean and quiet, and the bed was one of the most comfortable we have slept in. Eating options available around the hotel includes the excellent Daikokuya Ramen across the hotel. Japanese Village Plaza, a few steps away from the hotel also provided many options for a quick bite. However, there isn't much night life around the hotel.

Reviews.Title: “Recommend for a downtown business trip”
Reviews.Author: katyfair
Reviews.Content: Love the little tokyo area, and this (modern) Japanese-style hotel fitted right in. Staff were very friendly and helpful in person (though less so when I tried to skype for recommendations on travel from the airport, and the possibility of an early check-in - so all I can say is to give them a second chance). I did get an early check-in, which was great after a flight from Australia. Room was lovely, and I recommend the local Japanese restaurants.

Reviews.Title: “Disappointing stay but some good things, too”
Reviews.Author: spyyyyyke
Reviews.Content: Reading the reviews, there must be very different rooms all over this hotel. My experience was pretty negative. For my one-night stay: Good: Front desk, valet and cafe staff excellent. In fact, I dealt with two valet staff, one on arrival and one on departure. Both were extraordinarily helpful and charming. Bed was very comfortable, room safe a good size (held my 17" laptop and more), loved that the window opened, and in-room refrigerator was convenient. Bad: Otherwise stay was disappointing. Hallways & elevator very shabby and poorly-lit. Room needs repair (example: board covering a/c unit housing hanging an inch off wall), rug was dirty and stained, furniture was cheap, bathroom amenities, especially the soap and towels, were cheap. Supposedly had cable for Internet but no cable was in the desk drawer as it was supposed to be. When I called to have a cable delivered, the estimated delivery time was over 30 minutes, so I just went to bed. Overall depressing. I was traveling for business and for the price, I expected better. Front desk management was rude & uncompromising when I had a slight problem. Parking is provided by a company other than the hotel. Hotel says self-park is $17 but don't let the hotel charge you that much! I only had to pay $5 because I arrived before 9:30 a.m. Most stays would be $10 if you pay the garage's posted price instead of the price the hotel wants to stick you with.

Reviews.Title: “Good location, OK Place”
Reviews.Author: Spooner101
Reviews.Content: Walking in, the hotel is very clean and contemporary. The Staff is really friendly and helpful. The Valet is beyond nice, but if your paying $18 + tip then I would expect them to open the doors for my entire family. Lucky for us we had relatives that lived nearby and parked at their complex for a few days. The Location is perfect for anyone staying downtown, as well as the location is secure in the J-Town neighborhood with lots of great food. The hallways do need remodeling and feels like they have mold, as a musty smell overtakes you as you get off the elevators. The rooms are OK. The beds are hard as rocks, but good for my back. The pillows are extra firm. The size of the room was average but the bed were full size, The bathrooms are ok, only one sink. However I do like the Asian style of bidets that I so far have only found in Asian countries. There is no fan in the bathroom so make sure you bring some type of scent. House cleaning is very slow, so make sure you leave for a good half day to get a clean room upon return. We were situated at the end of the hall and on the 10th floor, making it the perfect stay for no noise. Take what you will, but it was a nice hotel and I would stay again if needed.

Reviews.Title: “decent stay”
Reviews.Author: Tam L
Reviews.Content: it was a decent stay for the price. the room and hotel is standard. great toilet! the only complaint is the parking situation.

Reviews.Title: “Peaceful quiet hotel, close to Union Station,”
Reviews.Author: mikesterDublin
Reviews.Content: This is a really nice hotel in the "Little Tokyo" district of Los Angeles. I stayed here for 2 nights after arriving at Union Station by train from Chicago. I had wanted to find a nice quiet and peaceful hotel, and after doing some research I choose this one. I was very pleased with my choice. The room I had was a very good size, and had some nice Japanese artwork and wallpaper. There was a coffee making machine and TV set. Also a nice desk and a light which could be adjusted up and down to make it brighter or dimmer. Best of all there was no noise or disruption at all that could be heard in the room. (Just what I wanted after 3 days on a train). The bathroom included a special heated and special Japanese loo seat. The hotel is about a 15 minute walk to Union station, and a 30 minute walk to the heart of downtown LA. There are lots of shops and Japanese restraunts close by, including a pretty good Supermarket on the next street up (near the Space Shuttle memorial). The reception area is very nice and there is a small shop in one section of it. I would like to return to this hotel and stay there again, and it is esspecially handy for anyone arriving at Union Station.

Reviews.Title: “Unique, Centrally Located and Could Use a Facelift”
Reviews.Author: J0hn0
Reviews.Content: Please note: this review is fairly detailed. The Miyako is one of the most centrally located hotels in the city, in the middle of Little Tokyo on First Street. From here you have easy access to the 101 and 5 freeways, downtown Los Angeles directly west, the arts district to the east, and the bars, restaurants and shops of J-Town all around you. The Metro Gold Line is literally 1 block away and connects to Union Station minutes away for access to all Metro services. It's one of the only hotels in the city that you can reach directly from LAX, Bob Hope or Ontario airports without even looking at a car. The hotel itself wasn't that great considering the price. I suspect if you pay for something more than the standard room I got, it might be nicer, but for the money I frankly expected a little higher quality.The second day of my stay there were maintenance guys working on the room across from mine, so I suspect it's clear to the owners the hotel is overdue for improvements. The hotel has the look and feel of a western-style hotel in Japan, with Japanese touches from the outside architecture to the room accents. My room on the 9th floor faced the Little Tokyo mall, and had the rare and welcome feature of an openable window. You can let in a breeze flavored with mingled scents of charbroiled teriyaki and the wild anise that grows downtown, which I totally enjoyed. The first thing I noticed about my room was that the door stuck. I went in and out often and each time it took three tries to force open the door. I had to master a technique and really put my shoulder into it. The room was pretty small, but managed to feature a really comfortable California king bed, a serious desk with drawers for storing your stuff and a comfy, stylish office chair. The lamp on the desk is not glaringly bright, provides a nice glow and yet is useful for reading and paperwork. Both sides of the bed feature generous night stands topped with Japanese-styled lamps. There is a long hanging Japanese paper lamp by the window that works on a reostat, making the room very atmospheric. The curtains over the window are bordered by wooden Japanese lattices that evoke a little Japanese ryokan feel. The closet is in the foyer behind a mirrored sliding door and is spacious. There is also a coffee service in a small recess adjacent to the closet. It sits on top of a heavy wood cabinet that houses the mini-fridge. There is no wireless access in the hotel except on the 2nd, 3rd and 11th floors and in the spa. I try to be objective in my reviews, but it's 2011 and they need to change that. Nobody carries a DSL cable around with them for their laptop. The bathroom is in need of remodeling, but is clean and functional. The door jam and walls are rife with nics and pitting around the corners from years of use. the toilet is awesome and like those in Japanese hotels features a bidet and heated seat. The shower has good pressure and a hand-held shower head to accommodate all heights. I paid one visit to the spa for a shiatsu massage and to check out the facilities. The bath and shower area are in need of maintenacne but again, are well-maintained. It kind of feels like an old familiar YMCA. Paint chips off the walls and old stubborn grime surrounds the doorway of the wet sauna. I was a little timid about taking off my spa sandals except for in the shower. The shiatsu massage was great and a good deal. Guests get a $10 off coupon so my 45-minute massage was $65 including the tip. A massage includes use of the entire facility which is a $20 value. The gym is small but really who cares about a gym in a hotel? There are lounges set up in the waiting room outside the massage room as well as outdoors on a small patio shaded by a wooden lattice and decorated with flowers and plants: a really nice feature. The massage room is totally relaxing, cool and comfortable and smells great. I wanted to visit the restaurant but didn't make it. The Tamon restaurant is run by the same company that owns Daikokuya and Ebisu here in J-Town and elsewhere, so I suspect it's delicious. The lounge features a full bar and karaoke, which I will experience if I stay here again. The little cafe in the lobby, Take 5, is a great place to chill. I'm sitting at a table outside it on the street as I write this. The coffee's good and the espresso drinks are okay. They have sandwiches and snacks, and a continental breakfast deal that's worth the money. There's comfortable seating inside and out and you can sit there and read or just hang out as long as you want. The staff with whom I interacted - mainly the front desk people and the spa attendant - were polite. I cannot go so far as to say friendly, but hey, polite works for me too. I did, however, feel more "accommodated" than welcome. If it weren't for my attempts to sort of cajole them, it would be hard for them to crack a smile. This isn't necessarily a criticism. It might just be the style of service the Miyako offers. Being sort of "left alone" is kind of nice. You can come and go as you please just like it's you're own apartment. However, compared to my experiences in Japan in general, I'm used to not only very friendly service but very friendly people in general. The Miyako is worth the stay for the location alone. I'm willing to overlook its faults in return for having downtown Los Angeles at my feet. I do hope some day soon that the hotel puts some money into standard improvements.

Reviews.Title: “Decent but Rather Not”
Reviews.Author: TheHonestWord
Reviews.Content: Decent if you need to do business directly in the J-town area of downtown LA but really nothing special; average 2 to 3 star hotel at the very MOST and that's being too generous for these drab, dated rooms and I honestly feel like some Holiday Inn's are actually more comfortable. Service is icey cold; we prepaid for executive kings but they gave them away by the time we checked in (at around 7pm so it wasn't that late) and didn't blink an eye when putting us in a room with double beds; no apologies from the staff or even an offer to any of us for a discount or comfort amenities - apparently it was our problem or so it was meant for us to feel that way. Overall not a pleasant stay and would recommend staying elsewhere if you can!

Reviews.Title: “Great stay adjacent to Downtown L.A.”
Reviews.Author: davidbh1453
Reviews.Content: Our stay at the Miyako was great, and we would definitely stay there again. The cheerful woman at the front desk (she looked like an older version of Lady Gaga) was completely accommodating in our request for one of the quieter rooms, even offering us the opportunity to pre-screen a few rooms before deciding for sure. That said, there's not much traffic in that area of L.A. on weekends, so I think any room would have likely been fine. The room was clean and spacious, with individual climate control. The window was able to be opened. The bed was a little soft for our taste (our only complaint). Parking next door in the Little Tokyo garage was very inexpensive on weekends, and at one exit time it was even free - no attendant was there when we left Sunday morning. The restaurants of the adjacent Little Tokyo shopping center were delicious, and wonderful for a mid-day snack or a full meal. We were in town for a show at the Ahmanson at Music Center, whjch was a short walk away - so no need for parking hassles at the theatre! We also walked to the gorgeous downtown YMCA for an excellent workout (the spa at the hotel was closed for renovations). Note that this particular YMCA charges guests a nominal fee, even if you have an AWAY sticker on your YMCA card. We were also able to get around the freeways easily from that location in L.A. (even though it was Carmageddon weekend), and took day or evening trips to Santa Monica, West Hollywood, Griffith Park, and Pasadena. We used the Burbank Airport instead of LAX, which was VERY convenient. All in all, a great stay!

Reviews.Title: “Bad service - customer comes last attitude”
Reviews.Author: PenghuVilla
Reviews.Content: Clean hotel. Okay location. Definitely focused on Japanese business travelers. We booked about 3 weeks before our stay, and I specifically asked for a non-smoking room. When we arrived, they informed me we would be in a smoking room. I complained. They said they didn't get my "non-smoking" request. To get into a non-smoking room, we had to pay an extra fee. What?! The next morning, they found my email from 3 weeks before, requesting the non-smoking room. But they refused to refund my "extra fee." I couldn't believe it. I won't stay here, again.

Reviews.Title: “Great accomodations, attentive staff"”
Reviews.Author: RandomThinker
Reviews.Content: We stayed 4 nights while my daughter attended an anime convention in LA. Room was clean, quiet, and very comfortable. Package offered a continental breakfast each day which was good and convenient. Staff was extremely friendly and attentive. First day there I didn't get my wake up call, and problem was corrected immediately (previous guest turned off phone volume). I have stayed here before and hope to return again.

Reviews.Title: “Excellent hotel in Downtown LA”
Reviews.Author: katelin_87
Reviews.Content: We stayed here for 7 nights in June 2011 and had a great experience. Our Executive Room was lovely and the staff were always friendly and helpful. We booked directly through the hotel's website and received a complimentary upgrade to an Executive Room, including complimentary breakfast. The room was fantastic! Very spacious and nicely decorated. It also included free wireless/wired internet, depending on what floor the room is on. The Miyako is located in a great area (in Little Tokyo). Plenty of Japanese restaurants in the surrounding streets, and about a 10 minute walk from the train and bus stations. There are also a couple of Japanese supermarkets and a Kinokuniya only a short walk away. Overall we had a very pleasant time and would not hesitate to stay here again.

Reviews.Title: “Quiet Nice Room”
Reviews.Author: ancher
Reviews.Content: I have just returned from Los Angeles, a three night stay in this very nice hotel in the heart of Little Tokyo. My room was excellent, exactly what I wanted, very quiet and a nice comfortable king bed. The TV was a little weird, didn't have the normal amount of channels you'd usually find at a hotel, but I didn't really care about that. They did have HBO which I took advantage of one night. And the service was very friendly, especially the car valets who would get my car lickety split when I wanted to venture out into the teeming morass of the greater LA area. The only downside for me was the lack of Wifi in the room...I'm new to WiFi though and am not sure that's a normal thing to have in a hotel room. They did have a DSL connection (which didn't work with my Ipad) and there was WiFi in the lobby. I was there for art, and the hotel is just one block from the Geffen Contemporary Art building which was showing "Art in The Streets", a show about graffiti. It is one big spectacular show and it turns out Mondays are free thanks to Banksy (until Aug. 8th, 2011). Thanks, Banksy! The area around the hotel has moxie (as my friend Tony described it) and I'd have to agree. There are plenty of people on the streets, lots of good restaurants all around and in a very safe feeling neighborhood. I ate at Mr. Ramen across the street (very good) and at a sushi place in the Little Tokyo Village next door to the hotel. Downtown LA is practically the only part of LA that isn't crushed with cars, so I enjoyed being there as a respite from my travels in my rental car around the area looking at art as mentioned. Don't miss LACMA (parking in the rear) and the Hammer Museum and Moca, there's plenty of art in LA, a beautiful Rembrandt at the Hammer Museum. Art (and what all else) abounds in beautiful Los Angeles!

Reviews.Title: “Great for Japanese, just OK for westerners”
Reviews.Author: Tzantushka
Reviews.Content: Think of a 1980's American movie with a hotel scene... then you are close. The Miyako's attractions are a reasonable price and proximity to Downtown LA. The majority of guests are Japanese - makes sense, located in little Tokyo - but as a business hotel the Miyako lets you down in a few ways: 1) breakfast is average for the price, 2) parking is either valet or off-site somewhere, and 3) the general facilities are getting 'tired'. For a one-night stay, then it's fine. You'll just need to accept the noisy airconditioning. On the flip side the positives are; friendly staff (especially the older Japanese workers) and free internet, there's also a selection of restaraunts close by - just don't arrive late in the evening as choice is limited.

Reviews.Title: “Don't stay here unless you are Japanese...”
Reviews.Author: Rolig
Reviews.Content: We were four colleagues staying at the hotel. Two had to change their rooms because they were so bad and didn't even have a closets. My room had a closet but had a bad smell and really should be updated. However, the bed was nice and comfortable. The only one who got a nice room was our Japanese colleague. Do not get your room through Expedia because it will not include the free breakfast. The breakfast is $20. If you make the reservation directly through the hotel you will get the free breakfast. We had a breakfast meeting but I didn't want to pay $20 since my colleagues had a free breakfast. I asked if I could buy a cup of coffee and was told I could not but I could go downstairs and buy coffee in the cafe. Downstairs I asked at the front desk if I could at least get a $10 rebate for the breakfast. I was told I could not since I made my reservation through Expedia. The people at the hotel were not very friendly and when I left the hotel with my suite cases the door man didn't even hold up the door for me. The hotel location is great for being down town Los Angeles.

Reviews.Title: “Good, Safe Location for Downtown LA”
Reviews.Author: Susan999
Reviews.Content: Stayed at this hotel for one night for business purposes. Needed quick access to the general downtown LA area and this hotel was situated in a safe and convenient location. As some reviewers have already noted, parking is not free (about $17/nt for self parking, and $19/nt for valet parking), so remember to add that cost in when budgeting. Overall, good, clean hotel.

Reviews.Title: “exceeded expectations”
Reviews.Author: anemonefish
Reviews.Content: Location in Little Tokyo on SE side of downtown LA is convenient and accessible. Both valet and public parking adjacent. Lots of restaurants and shops, and an easy walk to cultural center, city hall, and Olvera Street historic area. Staff was great, from checkin to checkout. Good value. We arrived early and they accommodated us graciously. Breakfast buffet in the restaurant is a generous mix of tasty American and Japanese dishes. Coffee/snack shop in the lobby offers continental breakfast. as well. Room on top (executive) floor was spacious, comfortable, and neat with a large window that could be opened for fresh air - live plants. Recommend upper floors to avoid noise. One niggling complaint: the iron was tethered to the ironing board with a coiled security cable, making ironing a little difficult. Now, the stellar: we had a morning meeting so checked out early and left our luggage with the bellman and told the valet roughly when we'd be departing. When we returned to the hotel after lunch, our car was ready and waiting with our luggage already stowed away. Top tier service for a mid-range cost.

Reviews.Title: “Great Location in little tokyo”
Reviews.Author: bkc2009
Reviews.Content: The location was great within little tokyo. It feels like actually living in the city. Just across the street, there were japanese restaurants and there are many shops around it. The room was also great with asian decoration that is not typical in other hotels. However the bathtub decor seem to be older with white tiles. There is those japanese toilet seats that clean ur private parts and those are also not typical and interesting. Staff was helpful and answer questions well. There is also a spa and massage place on 3rd floor that we didnt get to try. Parking is $19 with valet and $16 without valet with in and out privilege . But because we checked in around 11, we parked at the adjacent structure for only total of $8 but with no in and out privilege. The view was also good, you can see downtown los angeles skyline from the hotel room. Also, it was only 2 mins drive away from clubs district in los angeles. Overall, this was the best stay out of three nights i had in los angeles.

Reviews.Title: “An Efficient & Tidy Little Hotel”
Reviews.Author: honurider
Reviews.Content: I've stayed here twice on business trips, each of them for 4 days at a time. It's a cute little hotel. The staff is very helpful and the lobby has boba tea, green tea, hot drinks, sandwiches, salad and more. I had a shiatsu massage at the Spa there and it was very good. Just know that Shiatsu massage is not your ordinary deep tissue massage...it's really very different. The room is always clean and I had no complaints about any of it, except maybe that the fridge makes noise all night. The restaurant there is good, but I prefer to walk around the corner to Japanese Village Plaza & eat at Frying Fish. It's amazingly good. And there's the Nijaya Market in Japanese Village too. You can get food there and keep it in your fridge in your room. On Fri & Sat. nights they have outdoor karaoke in the plaza too. Parking your car there is $19.80 a night, with all in & out privileges. I'd stay here again. It's a good value for the price.

Reviews.Title: “Great Japantown location, good japanese food, but shabby, tired rooms”
Reviews.Author: devidas
Reviews.Content: 2 nights in 'deluxe' King. The only deluxe item appeared to be the bidet toilet. All Japanese hotels provide kimono & slippers - except this one! Paint peeling prolifically in the bathroom, no basin plug, bath faucet would not seal when showering - wasting precious LA water! Breakfast restaurant poor - 'hot' items were lukewarm, however evening restaurant was very good. Japantown has safe sidewalks, many good Japanese restaurants, supermarkets, shops and museums nearby. Staff were friendly, most speak Japanese. Would definitely return if rooms were refurbished.

Reviews.Title: “Really comfortable rooms for an affordable price”
Reviews.Author: newlanti
Reviews.Content: Our room was upgraded for free and we got a complementary breakfast each morning we stayed. For the amount we paid the rooms were very comfortable. They were clean and at a nice temperature, The bathroom was a clean and a generous size with delicious Aveda toiletries. The staff went out of their way to be helpful. The area was a little dead at night but I felt safe walking around and everything was easily accessible from nearby metro stop. Many affordable Japanese restaurants on the same street as the hotel. Check out the "Family Mart" across the road but proceed towards the back of the store with caution if you have small children with you.

Reviews.Title: “Don't do it...”
Reviews.Author: julitita
Reviews.Content: Okay, this hotel is so far below my standards I can't even begin. Gross. Try the Kyoto Grand around the corner. It looked much nicer. Weird, dark, noisy, dirty, gross...did not feel safe. I can't believe the good review. The only positive thing to say is that the people who worked there were very nice.

Reviews.Title: “Good deal in downtown”
Reviews.Author: pusmes
Reviews.Content: I stayed here for 3 days back in August. I was there to attend a trade show at LA Convention Center. Its a good setting, value for money and a clean place. I kept my expectations low since its a downtown hotel, but I didn't have any bad experience. The only issue i have is with the parking garage which is right behind this hotel and over a shopping complex. That place is kind of shady and smelling. Valet would have been a better option.

Reviews.Title: “Ok... but not a good location”
Reviews.Author: zoejmcgill
Reviews.Content: The people working at the hotel were very friendly.... they gave us a map and highlighted which routes to take and how to get there and what areas to avoid... because downtown LA is DODGY! We were scared, thinking we were going to get mugged in downtown La... which is unfortunate for The Miyako Hotel..... If I went back to LA I would not stay in downtown la... maybe somewhere close to Santa Monica Beach, because everywhere in La takes forever to get to. But if you really want to stay downtown then the Miyako is a good place to stay. Awesome Japanese restaurants across the road - such good value too!

Reviews.Title: “Best of Little Tokyo”
Reviews.Author: bksgrrrl
Reviews.Content: Although it's been around awhile, the Miyako is well maintained, with an international ambiance that should work well for both business and leisure travellers. Rooms are spacious, attractively decorated, very clean. Location is perfect for those who travel by train (one Metro stop from Union Station), with excellent restaurants, shops, and museums in the Little Tokyo neighborhood. Staff is professional yet cordial and attentive. Have breakfast or a snack in Take 5 Cafe in the lobby, a great place to plan your day and people watch. One morning we were fascinated to observe the hotel's flower arranger as she effortlessly prepared a stunning seasonal bouquet for display next to the elevators. We were on a long distance train trip from Seattle to Chicago, and our stay at the Miyako left us rested and refreshed for the next leg of our journey.

Reviews.Title: “Great Stay... love the local Sushi”
Reviews.Author: rawkneee
Reviews.Content: We had a great stay at the Miyako. Location was great, specially since we love Sushi. there are many great sushi spot within walking distance. the Tokyo mall is right next door. Felt safe the entire time we were there. Bed was very comfortable and the room was very clean and decorated nicely. Large flat screen tv and a prety fancy toilet. The toilet had all kinds of features; wash, massage, heat. Free Internet in rooms was cool too. Valet parking was a bit high at $20 a day, but besides that, a great stay. We stayed here amd went to see a show at the Staples Center. it was a quick $10 taxi ride to the Staples Center from here.

Reviews.Title: “Pretty Average Hotel”
Reviews.Author: Maikolo
Reviews.Content: I have stayed in this hotel many times. I don't have anything negative to say about it, but it is really just average. I love the location because it is located in china town and there are hundreds of neat shops and restaurants to choose from. Really cool high tech japanese toilets.

Reviews.Title: “We will come back”
Reviews.Author: taybaseball
Reviews.Content: We found this hotel on the internet-taking our daughter to school and needed a place that was easy, economical and in a safe area. The Miyako was all of these. It was a pleasant surprise to be right in downtown to feel safe and close to so many things. We enjoyed the Japanese Village right next door. All the staff was not only helpful but made us feel so welcome. Room was fine and the beds comfortable. Our room faced First st. and it was so quiet. We will definetly be back as long as our daughter is at school in LA

Reviews.Title: “Excellent value!”
Reviews.Author: beaufortia
Reviews.Content: Very convenient and reasonable. Staff are better in person than on the phone. Enjoyed the stay and will stay there again given the chance.

Reviews.Title: “Dissappointed with arrogance of front desk staff”
Reviews.Author: mebharkins
Reviews.Content: My wife and I stayed four nights visiting our son who is beginning a master's program nearby. Our first three night were booked online. A Thursday at a weekday rate and a Friday/Saturday at a lower weekend rate which included a continental breakfast. A forth (Sunday) night was added during our stay using the front desk staff, who offered the forth night at the "same reduced weekend rate". Monday morning we were turned away from the continental breakfast. The young woman at the front desk informed us the continental breakfast was only offered with an online booking. When asked why she had not informed us of that when we booked the forth day with her, she replied we had not asked. I explained that when I booked the forth day, it was our expectation that the "same rate" meant including breakfast. She became very rude and simply ignored me. It is still difficult for me to understand why any hotel would allow customers to leave on such a sour note over one $3 breakfast after a four night visit. Looking back I can't see anything we did wrong. The only possible explanation in their defense I can think of is a cultural difference between the mostly Japanese staff and us? In my defense, n LA I believe it is reasonable to expect that the "same rate" should have included the same or equal room and breakfast..

Reviews.Title: “If the service staff were professional”
Reviews.Author: WorldCulture
Reviews.Content: The location of the hotel is convenient, surrounded with many Japanese restaurants which we enjoyed. The hotel was clean enough. However the evening-shift staff were pretty rude which was a contrast to the day-time staff.

Reviews.Title: “Better Then Most in LA for the price!!”
Reviews.Author: vinividivori
Reviews.Content: I'm a native Angeleno that recently moved to Las Vegas. Over the past seven year, I've been back to LA numerous times - and always love the idea of staying in my home town as a tourist. I usually try to find a hotel around 100.00 per night (less if I can find it), that's decent, and close to what I want to see. I was making a day trip to MOCA's Geffen Contemporary and chose the Miyako because it was under 100.00 and a block away from the museum! Being smack dab in the middle of all the great food in Little Tokyo was a big plus too! I booked a Standard King through Priceline - who had a better room offered at the same price than other hotel websites. It totally pays to look around. My room was spotless, the bed beautiful and comfy and the shower hot - day or night. In room safe was great for storing my laptop, extra camera equipment and wallet when I wanted to travel light. I had a room facing 1st Street and the only problem I had was the late-night patrons of the much revered Daikokuya Noodle House directly across the street. On the weekends they stay open until 3 or 4 in the morning - serving up perfect late-night post-drinking bowls of steaming ramen. There is always a 15 person wait there - so in wee hours it can get a little, um, "celebratory" - but that's all part of the great urban groove this part of town has going on! As an over-40 female, I felt totally safe, even roaming the streets late at night by myself taking pictures. Overall - the Miyako will definitely be my first choice when visiting LA from here on out!

Reviews.Title: “can't wait to go back”
Reviews.Author: marinegirl5
Reviews.Content: My husband and I stayed one night and it was great. We only paid 99$ for the night which you all know for a nice hotel in downtown LA is questionable. The hotel itself was very modern on the inside & very inviting. There's a cute little deli/coffee stand with great latte and tea drinks, and a nice gift shop. For the price I didn't expect any of that, not to mention the immaculant marble looking floors in the lobby. The room was very modern and more than could have been hoped for. The bathroom was a disappointment as others mentioned, the grout is a little shoddy, it seems they remodeled everything but the bathroom. There was however heated toilet seat and a bidet! There was a $20 fee to park in their garage, but it seems possible to find street parking. The fun part for me was all the activity in the neighborhood. It was perfectly safe and we walked around at dark with no worries. There's a cute little shopping village next door with many great gift shops since you are in little Tokoyo there are a ton of authentic places to eat. There's a cute little diner directly across the street from the hotel open until 2am. We enjoyed the sushi. I can't wait to go back for more fun food and shopping!

Reviews.Title: “Little Tokyo Area”
Reviews.Author: 88travelbug
Reviews.Content: This Hotel was situated in little tokyo. Lax airport to Miyako cost about 25 dollars per person using a shuttle bus which offers door to door service 24 hours a day, located outside the airport. Or u can alternatively catch a taxi or the flyaway service which is the cheapest option. Wish i knew about this option before I arrived. Nice looking hotel room, I had a large room with 2 large beds, tv, table, iron, hair dryer etc. complimentary Aveda goodies. Japanese style toilet, with seat warming features. However every night I stayed, there was a buzzing/humming sound, annoyed me but because I was so tired I usually fell asleep after a while. I never mentioned this to the receptionist so im not sure if this was on every floor or just the floor I stayed on. Located nearby many japanese restaurants and shops. around the corner less than a few minutes walk to the little tokyo metrolink station and less than 5 minutes to the main station grand union. Used the grand union station to travel to universal studios and the walk of fame area. Used the bus service to get to santa monica beach area. Concierge gave me maps and bus times. Felt safe at all times of the day.

Reviews.Title: “Very much like staying in Tokyo”
Reviews.Author: Yamhillbilly
Reviews.Content: Staying at the Miyako Hotel was very much like staying in a mid-level business/tourist hotel in Tokyo. I don't mean that in a romanticized "whisked off to the Orient" way, but instead in a very realistic way. And it is no surprise, being part of the Miyako hotel chain in Japan, and being located in the heart of downtown's Little Tokyo district, and attracts a largely Japanese clientele. It is an older facility, in decent repair, very clean, very functional. Excellent value for location: obvious choice if doing business in Little Tokyo / Arts District, but also close to City Hall and the rest of downtown, Union Station, fashion district, etc. Served by the gold line light rail, Little Tokyo / Arts District stop. A couple of random notes: the hotel is kind of wedged in and hard to notice from the street; it has a nice lobby, but from the sidewalk, there isn't a huge entry. Also, a note about breakfasts: if your room rate includes breakfast, pay attention to whether it is the buffet in the restaurant or the continental breakfast. The continental breakfast is basically croissants and coffee in the lobby snack stand. The buffet in the restaurant is a utilitarian mix of American (eggs, bacon, sausage, etc) and Asian (rice, congee, natto, etc). Not at all fancy, but fine. I thouroughly enjoyed being transported to my days of doing business in Japan!

Reviews.Title: “Quality Hotel at a Reasonable Price”
Reviews.Author: wanderer
Reviews.Content: Downtown LA needs more hotels like this--good hotels at a good price. Though it's a few blocks outside the Downtown core, it is in one of the livelier areas of Downtown LA. The Miyako caters to Japanese travelers and tour groups, but works fine for Americans. It's an even better location now that the Gold Line light rail to Union Station, Pasadena, and East LA stops one block from the hotel (the Red Line subway is about a 10 minute walk away). They need to do some cosmetic repairs, like repainting the buttons in their elevator.

Reviews.Title: “Very Clean, quaint, and close to everything!”
Reviews.Author: tangx2
Reviews.Content: Check in was a very easy. The process took 5 mins. The staff was very polite and efficient. The lobby was quiet and spotless. Also, I found out if you are going to take your car in and out of the garage frequently, you might as well just pay the $17 validation fee opposed to the rate of $10, because the garage charges you $5-10 everytime you leave the garage. The hotel just charges you $17 for the whole day, and you can go in and out as many times as you want. The room was very clean and comfortable. It wasn't luxorious, but it was perfect for the cheap price. We just needed a place to sleep and take a comfortable shower. Love their shower! Super relaxing, and no hot water problems. Cool toilet seat. It's got a butt warmer. Haha. The view was good. We were on the front side of the hotel, which overlooked the entrance and the cute japanese restaurants across the street. There was many stores and restaurants around hotel, which made it very convienent. I would definitely go back, especially for the price!!

Reviews.Title: “Value for money and excellent location”
Reviews.Author: smp_auckland
Reviews.Content: This hotel is good value for money. I had a large room with double bed, TV cabinet, safe, wardrobe and bathroom. It is on a main road in Little Tokyo, close to restaurants and the Little Tokyo shopping district to the south. Many reasonably priced Japanese restaurants nearby, and safe at night with a reasonable number of people out eating (for a single woman travelling alone in downtown LA this is important). The rooms are a little tired, eg scratches on the table legs, shower not always piping hot, and wi-fi wireless not ethernet (even though a cable in the room). However, it was clean, my room was always really well made up, and the staff were always helpful and pleasant to deal with. I was on a room facing the street and there was some traffic noise, and occasionally some music, but it was always over around 12. In terms of the restaurants, the Tamon on level 2 offers a buffet but it seems to cater to Japanese tourists. It was passable but over-priced for the quality. Cafe Take5 downstairs in the lobby is just OK for a breakfast, and it has a good supply of drinks and snacks, but I'd recommend going out somewhere downtown for a fresh bagel and better coffee (an espresso machiato is the only option in LA imho).

Reviews.Title: “Lovely find in Los Angeles”
Reviews.Author: arachne
Reviews.Content: Thanks to tripadvisor, my husband and I stayed at the Miyako hotel for a total of three days in February, going to and from Los Angeles,via Amtrak,from Oregon. The hotel is convenient to the beautiful,circa 1939 Union Station. The two(actually, three) "executive" rooms we stayed in were large and well-appointed (down to the heated toilet seats with bidet!), the bedside lights were adequate for reading, the staff was very attentive(when we complained about the construction noise on the first morning, they immediately moved us to another room). Room service brought up nicely-presented, well-prepared Japanese food. The shiatsu massage and little spa was fabulous,very reasonably priced, and open late in the evening. The surrounding area was safe to walk in and very interesting--don't' miss the Japanese American National Museum. I'd be wary,though,of the nearby Kyoto Grand hotel, where we got kicked out of the garden by a bouncer, after the front desk receptionist invited us to see it--Poor management, perhaps? We also found a little gem of a restaurant/bar called Wurstkuche, very walkable at 800 E. 3rd Ave--try the vegetarian, chicken-ginger-apricot, hot Italian sausages,or a variety of others, all house-made, with many beers on tap. The only negatives were a noisy elevator shaft or something(we thought maybe it was the wind sock on the roof), and the construction going on at the police headquarters down the block from the front of the building--so get rooms in the back if the beeping of tractors bothers you. The Miyako and environs was a very pleasant, accessible surprise in an otherwise pretty difficult-to-maneuver post-industrial city.

Reviews.Title: “Nice hotel, little Toyko”
Reviews.Author: tencom
Reviews.Content: Nice clean room, small continental breakfast, the 12:00 checkout was nice since many hotels are 11:00. I would stay here again, in fact my wife is ready to go back. Nice AAA discount.

Reviews.Title: “Significantly overrated”
Reviews.Author: Paul99501
Reviews.Content: The Miyako was okay but nothing more, and not nearly as nice as the Westin Bonaventure, where I have stayed on previous trips to the downtown area of LA. Staff at the Miyako was very friendly and helpful, and it had free internet in the rooms, a definite plus. But the internet was spotty -- very slow a lot of the time. I was upgraded to an "executive" room on the 10th floor, but it was dark (not enough lighting) and had a tired feel to it. Getting a little shabby around the edges. TV was old and only got about 20 channels, with no options for movies, games, etc. Bathroom was mediocre -- the showerhead was crappy. I also found the hotel a bit too noisy -- there was a lot of mechanical noise, squealing elevators and things like that, even though I was far from the elevator. Valet parking with unlimited in and out was about $22 per night, including all taxes. The hotel fitness center was small and is part of the spa, so you have to pay extra to use it (ripoff, in this day and age). The area, Little Tokyo, has a lot of homeless people and is quite small (basically about 2 square blocks, so it's good for a couple of hours at most of looking around, but really is pretty uninspiring. I wouldn't stay here again. For about the same price, the Westin is better all around.

Reviews.Title: “Close to station”
Reviews.Author: stlous1992
Reviews.Content: Stayed there for 2 nights. Close to Union station - used subway to Universal Studio and Flyaway bus to LAX. The room was dated but clean. The hotel was surrounded by Japanese restaurants which was good for Japanese food lovers. A good located hotel if you rely on public transport.

Reviews.Title: “i love this little hotel”
Reviews.Author: aquitoeternity
Reviews.Content: do yourself a favor and visit the spa - get a shiatsu massage. - very affordable for the quality of service - dont worry you can thank me later. also: get a green tea smoothie from the cafe on the ground floor.

Reviews.Title: “Nice.”
Reviews.Author: Jetboy
Reviews.Content: Pros: The location affords the traveler easy access to downtown LA's landmarks. Little Tokyo is as charming as ever. Lots of dining and shopping places around. The room we stayed in was renovated. Nice comfortable beds. Aveda products in the bathroom. Massage in the spa was incredible and reasonably priced. Two Lovely receptionists in the am. Very attentive bellhops. Cons: Big LCD TVs with analog reception. Internet can be very slow most of the time. The sink backs up. $18 + tax for parking. There was one particular elderly person working the front desk who was not accommodating and couldn't care less. As long as you avoid her, you'll be fine.

Reviews.Title: “Nice clean hotel in a safe area in L.A”
Reviews.Author: Ahmed A
Reviews.Content: Me and one of my best friends stayed at this hotel during our 5 nights in L.A. Hotel was quiet clean and the staff were very helpful with directions and tips, it is located in a very safe area in Down town L.A ( 2 blocks from LAPD). Downtown L.A in my opinon isnt a safe city at all therefore i was happy to stay in this hotel which was full of nice japanese resturants and people and atmosphere just around. You need a car to get around L.A( hollywood , beverly hills, bel air) as the metro system is not well conected in this city also it is not recommended at night. there is a metro stop 5 min walk from the hotel . I would recommend this hotel for anyone staying in L.A with a car .

Reviews.Title: “overlooking little tokyo restaurants”
Reviews.Author: patsandsox
Reviews.Content: Very reasonable value, esp compared with Kyoto (old New Otani) 2 blocks away; hotel has very little public space, but renovated room in top floor was spacious, well furnished. Very convenient location, a 100 step stroll away from all the little Tokyo restaurants and shops. Rooms in Kyoto, by contrast, were much more dated/worn, although much nicer public spaces including roof garden and restaurants in latter.

Reviews.Title: “Great location for japantown and downtown...bit of a drive from main sights”
Reviews.Author: Brighton_Claire
Reviews.Content: We paid a very cheap rate for a basic room and were upgraded to a suite so we were loving it!!! The suite was very ice, lovely aveda products in bathroom too. Lovely comfortable bed. Breakfast was awful - perhaps good if you are Japanese, but not good for westerns. Did not inspire me eat anything else there. The congerice was very helpful - even priting off bus times for us. Parking is pricey, but this is inevitable anywhere in LA I think. Try the japanese restaurants round the corner - lots of good ones. Also a bar serving local wines, beers and kababs and falfels was very good.

Reviews.Title: “Great hotel, beautiful rooms”
Reviews.Author: SushieG
Reviews.Content: Very clean, nice room with great basics. Extras like Japanese style lamps, Aveda products in bathroom. Staff very friendly. Quiet neighbourhood so we weren't up all night. Safe and reasonable clean area. Close to train stations and park, although not exactly in the coolest part of town.

Reviews.Title: “awsome”
Reviews.Author: MykeH
Reviews.Content: service was excellent, great location, near everything. i thought it was a clean enviroment, from indoor to outdoor.

Reviews.Title: “Very good hotel Downtown”
Reviews.Author: teklord
Reviews.Content: We stayed at this hotel during out 3 day trip to Los Angeles and we were very positively surprised. Considering the price paid for our room, and based on our previous experience with US hotels, we haven't expected much. But the Miyako is not like other hotels. Although it is rated as a 3 stars hotel, it can easily hold pace with a lot of 4 stars hotels in an upper price category. The room was very clean and the staff was very nice and helpful. All in all we got very good quality for our moneyand we will book the hotel again during our trip to LA.

Reviews.Title: “Exceptional value, fun Japantown location, cool modern/Japanese design with character”
Reviews.Author: LAtripper24
Reviews.Content: We enjoyed our stay, found it a really exceptional value, will go back. The hallways were a little dingy w/ low ceilings, but that would be my biggest complaint; where it counted, the Miyako delivered nicely: good service, nice room, clean, great bed. We sprung for the deluxe room, glad I did. Cute Japanese/modern design (a refreshing break from the generic, mediocre, cookie-cutter aesthetic of most mid-priced hotels), super comfy duvet, fun location, w/tons of Japanese restaurants and shops at your doorstep--more fun than staying elsewhere in downtown LA. We have stayed in the Omni many times in the past, and although this ain't it, for the money saved (like upwards of $200 a night), I was very happy with the Miyako.

Reviews.Title: “The perfect location for eating and shopping Japanese style.”
Reviews.Author: cincodeperro
Reviews.Content: Stayed just one night, wished we could have stayed longer. Located in the middle of Little Tokyo, the hotel has valet parking for a very reasonable rate, super friendly staff, top of the line amenities in the bathroom, state of the art toilet!!, best bed ever found in a hotel, will stay there again and again.

Reviews.Title: “Average Hotel...”
Reviews.Author: jules025
Reviews.Content: The front desk people are not very friendly, the tour desk lady was extremely unfriedly - no smile, no greeting and makes you feel like you are the rude one. Maybe it is just me, thinking that most Japanese are friendly. The room was big, the toilet is quite big, but the room looks old.....the power switches are at odd places, very high on the wall (had to use a chair) or very low near the entrance. Our flight wasnt till 11pm, so we pay extra to stay till 6pm. Our room pass didn't work when we try to use it at 4pm. Had to go to the front desk to get it 're-programmed'. The front desk didn't even say anything, only - it should work now. I dont know if I will recommend this hotel to others...

Reviews.Title: “Nice Hotel”
Reviews.Author: CrystalFell
Reviews.Content: We stayed here for 4 nights for our Los Angeles trip. We were pleasantly suprised. The hotel was pretty modern and our bed was fantastic. Very big and very comfortable. There was a downside, after a 12 hour flight they wouldnt let us check in at 11am unless we paid $40.00 extra a night for an upgrade. We declined and had to walk around los angeles for 4 hours before being allowed to check in. Hard Work. Other than that we had a nice stay, though the area a little rough.

Reviews.Title: “Unique, modern, taste of Japan”
Reviews.Author: STupa
Reviews.Content: My husband and I needed a place to stay the night before we caught Amtrak so chose this hotel because of its location and reviews and we were delighted. I would have liked to stay longer as there are many places to explore within an easy walk. We actually walked to the hotel from Union Station as it is less than half a mile, even though we had luggage (wheeled). Little Toyko is fascinating and within a block you can also get great Cuban food and other cuisines. The bus and rail services are excellent so you don't really need a car here. Our hotel room had a nice view, especially at night. Everything was modern styling in a gracious way and squeaky clean. The staff spoke good English and were helpful.

Reviews.Title: “Great for the price!”
Reviews.Author: ImAtTheBeach27
Reviews.Content: We just got back from LA and stayed at the Miyako Hotel in Little Tokyo and thought it was great for the price we paid. Our room was a decent size, everything was clean and worked. We had rented a car and the front desk staff was very helpful with directions, even printing maps for us off of Mapquest. The cleaning staff and bar/wait staff were also very friendly. All in all we thought it was great, simple hotel for the location and price. If you want something fancy with all the bells and whistles this isn't the place for you.

Reviews.Title: “beyond my expectations”
Reviews.Author: ryokox37
Reviews.Content: I stay there frequently when im visiting little tokyo for whatever event is going on and the location is great. I take the train and itâ€™s a 5 min cab ride from union station. Sorry but im not sure the distance if your traveling from LAX. The staff has always been friendly and courteous every time I checked in. I normally call about 2 weeks in advanced to get the room I want. The hotel itself has a wonderful spa and I karaoke bar on the 2nd floor, the service at both being well above my expectation. there is also a restaurant located in the lobby area but I havenâ€™t been there so I cant write about it, but I can say with great satisfaction that the breakfast bar / coffee bar was able to get me a prairie oyster (great anti-hangover drink). The rooms were very comfortable, I stay in the business class rooms with the very nice linins, the rooms have always been clean and met all and exceeded my expectations. Other reviews have said that the rooms have an odor, I have never experienced this at the hotel, and Iâ€™ve been staying there once a month for about 2 years. The bathrooms are nicely done with the "high tech" toilets and I love the oversized shower head. The carpeting in the rooms is typical hotel carpeting but honestly I donâ€™t care about that. The view is great of down town LA, and the wireless internet access was surprisingly fast, im talking T-1 fast. As I said before if you go with the business class room the beds are extremely comfortable and the linins are very soft and comfortable, the comforter is just so nice and soft. There is a safe, larger sized mini fridge, iron and ironing board, desk with plenty of outlets, phone, very stylish lamps, a couch with foot rest or a long couch, and a nice large flat screen TV. So to sum it up great service from the desk, very comfortable and very clean rooms, good price, great location, and great in hotel services. FIVE STARS!

Reviews.Title: “Lousy Front Desk Service!!!!!!”
Reviews.Author: fidlfreek
Reviews.Content: We arrived at 3:10 pm, 10 minutes after check-in began. However, our rooms hadn't been cleaned yet so we were asked to wait in the lobby. After 40 minutes the front desk guy finally just switched out our rooms. I told him I had never been asked to wait even 5 minutes before and could he give us something towards breakfast in the morning he just laughed at me and said "thats not included." I have NEVER been treated so rudely. TERRIBLE customer service. The rooms were decent, not smelly or loud (but they didn't face the street) like some of the reviews said. DO NOT accept a 3 star hotel from Hotwire (in downtown LA) for $73. It is this hotel which is so ghetto that even local calls cost 75 cents, the gym costs $10, and I didn't even bother with the internet because it wasn't free. What a rip off.

Reviews.Title: “Average stay at Miyako”
Reviews.Author: CentralCATraveler
Reviews.Content: We drove to L.A. to see a Lakers game. I was looking for a hotel near the Staples Center that wasn't too expensive. The price for the Miyako Hotel was reasonable, though parking cost extra. We ended up parking in a small lot near the hotel to pay less than their valet only service. The hotel was a bit worn, with stains on the carpet and the sink laminate was chipped. There was a hair on the sink area when we first inspected the bathroom. There was bidet, if you're into that...We had a room that was adjoined to another room and we could hear the people in next room talking and doing other more intimate things which kept us awake/woke us up. There were a few Japanese and Korean restaurants right across the street and there was a little cafe in the lobby. There was a spa in the hotel, but we didn't try it. The prices seemed reasonable though. Hotel caters to Japanese tourists. Average place, so pay more someplace else if you expect more.

Reviews.Title: “Just a regular hotel”
Reviews.Author: iceui2
Reviews.Content: The rooms weren't small, but they weren't large either. The hotel is located in downtown LA in Little Tokyo, so there are a lot of places to eat. Parking is rather expensive (~$17/day). The internet connection wasn't fast, but it wasn't ridiculously slow either. The hotel staff was friendly, although they did give us a smoking room even though we requested non-smoking. The automated toilets were interesting... overall, the hotel is pretty good for its value. It's one of the cheapest hotel in the city if you book through Priceline. Probably not a 3-star hotel, maybe a 2.5-star...

Reviews.Title: “Poor service, no heat, and bad smell, but close to transportation, activities”
Reviews.Author: gabriellia
Reviews.Content: The Miyako Hotel was the worst hotel I have ever stayed in, and I really hate to say that because it didn't have to be. I blame the staff who cared little for the comfort of guests, and acted as if having to interact with patrons was a big interruption to their casual conversations. My room had no heat, and I tried to switch rooms a few times, to no avail. They insisted on fixing the furnace, which was fine when the heat first stopped working, but was nonsensical by the third time! The staff even sent the bellman one morning when I woke up freezing -- and he tried to make up an excuse by saying that I didn't know how to use a thermostat, which was absolutely wrong and insulting. I gave up asking for a new room, and sat in coffee shops for warmth. LA had unusually cold temps, but that's still no excuse for not having a functional heater. To make matters worse, my room smelled like mildew and old trash. I should have switched rooms just for that (they ignored that request too), but I discovered by wandering around that the ENTIRE hotel had an old, unclean smell to it, like trash, cigarettes, and mildew. Housekeeping comes by early, and if you are not ready for them by 10:30am, they stick a nasty-gram under your door. Of course, I wasn't planning to be in my room that much, considering the cold and the smell, but on the two occasions I decided to return after breakfast to make a phone call and pick up some items, they let me know that I was not welcome to linger. Also, there were only two pillows on the bed, no extra blanket, and I could not get more when I asked the housekeeping staff. Parking is not easy, but be careful! The front desk will tell you it's cheaper to park with them, but if you park in the Little Toyko Mall parking garage, which is the SAME BUILDING, they will charge you less than half of what the Miyako charges. It cost me $62 for 8 days of parking; the Miyako was going to charge me $136 ($17/day for self park, $24/day for valet). What makes me frustrated most about the stay is not the poor service at the front desk, but the lost opportunity. The hotel could have had so much to offer. The shiatsu massage was one of the best I've ever had, though the spa was dirty and the reception was not very helpful and seemed stressed. The cafe in the lobby was convenient and offered good food and service. Even the gift shop clerk was friendly and nice. Best of all was the location -- in the heart of Little Toyko, it's close to public transportation, downtown activities, a huge selection of restaurants, and has a wonderful view of city hall. I enjoy the Japanese culture and was looking forward to this visit. It's a shame that the Miyako Hotel had such poor execution. I am a quiet, respectful guest who never complains and I travel frequently on business. This is the first time I felt motivated to write a review and warn others. My recommendation: Stay here for the location, the local restaurants, and the shiatsu massage. Have a high tolerance for the cold and damp, and be able to ignore bad smells and awful service. The rates aren't low enough to account for the poor treatment of guests. And despite what I read, I did not encounter any language problems, only attitudinal.

Reviews.Title: “Stay somewhere else”
Reviews.Author: sisigirl
Reviews.Content: I had an unpleasant and unsatisfactory experience in Miyako. I made my reservation online at Miyako official website. I reserved King size bed. When I checked in, I got 2 double beds instead. The gentleman at the front desk told me that room-type is not guarantee when making the reservation. When I made my reservation online, I was required to enter my credit card information. Quote from the website: â€œAll reservations require a valid credit card number and expiration date in order to guarantee your reservationâ€�. I didnâ€™t see anything that says room-type is not guarantee when I made my reservation. I told the gentleman at the front desk that I am not happy with the 2 double beds. He then told me that the room that they assigned to me (the 2 doubles) is a free upgrade to deluxe/luxury. I asked him what is the difference between a basic and a deluxe/luxury room. He told me the furniture are better. My room # was 405 and I am NOT convinced that it is a deluxe/luxury room. Why? Part of the desk is a just a piece of dark brown wood attached to the wall with no leg. Another desk with light brown color serves as an extension of the dark brown wood on the wall. Not to mention the desk has major scratches and dents all over. I did not want to waste my time to go back to the front desk and ask for a room switch. My conclusion is I will not stay in Miyako again and I will not recommend this hotel to anyone. There was another unpleasant experience during my stay in Miyako. When I went back to the room the next day, the cleaning crew left a dirty towel on the floor inside the room.

Reviews.Title: “overpriced”
Reviews.Author: pettaspagna
Reviews.Content: The hotel is quite overpriced. Position is good, but you pay for the internet, you pay for the parking because it's not free ... breakfast is not included. For all these reasons, i found this hotel expensive, even though the position is good and secure, and the hotel is clean and nice.

Reviews.Title: “more than your money's worth”
Reviews.Author: sirtravel
Reviews.Content: Stayed here for business and found the hotel excellent. Located in Little Tokyo, it is perfectly located if you have business in downtown LA or surrounding areas (like Pasadena). Got a room rate of $109 on their web site and they upgraded me to the executive floor. Really didn't use the hotel except for sleeping, but the rooms were big and comfortable, the toiletries were great (Aveda products), and there were lots of good Asian food choices close to the hotel. Checked out the breakfast buffet and opted to walk down the block to Starbuck's instead -- $15 for the buffet did not seem like a good value. Rather than valet parking for $19, I used the parking lot next door (entrance just to the right of the hotel) for $14 -- not a big difference but didn't need the convenience of the valet. I might not stay here if I came as a tourist as the area is somewhat bleak, although there are a couple of museums close by and you can walk to the Dorothy Chandler Pavillion and the new Disney theatre. But the area is a bit dodgy at night with lots of homeless just a few blocks away. More business than tourist hotel. But I would definitely return for business.

Reviews.Title: “Great for frequent travelers”
Reviews.Author: txsteveh
Reviews.Content: The Miyako is one of those hotels not to many people seem to know about. I travel often to Los Angeles,30 weeks or more out of the year on business, and find my self trying new hotels all the time. This hotel has been consistent with every stay and is always a good place rest. The rooms are quiet, clean, and good sized. The executive rooms do offer a nice big LCD TV and upgraded bed which is nice for a small +$20 or so a day. The +$20 still makes this one of the most affordable hotels around the downtown area. The staff is great and know who I am when i walk in and the little coffee shop downstairs is great. They also have a couple very good restaurants as well as a gym and massages. Little tokyo is right next door where there is another 20 or so restaurants to choose from. All in all I never mind staying here when on business. I must have stayed here no less then 15 weeks the last 12 months and I have never had any issues.

Reviews.Title: “Clean Place, Friendly Staff”
Reviews.Author: jodcha
Reviews.Content: I won a bid for this hotel thru Priceline for $75/night. Most sites rate this hotel 3-star, Tripadvisor rate this 2-star. Hotel exterior looks old, but once you step in, it's a different story. The lobby is bright and clean and spacious. Parking was ~$20 per 24-hour. Its valet. I had a good experience, because they upgraded us to "Tokyo Executive Room". What a surprise even I booked this thru Priceline. Apparently, there were two groups of tour (from Japan I guess) checked in before us (We checked in really late night), thus all standard/deluxe rooms had been taken, we got an upgrade. The room was very good, bed very comfy, nice decor, given that I only paid $75 for an executive room in downtown LA, it was a very good deal. But I am not sure if I would say the same thing if I was in a standard room. Due to the fact that the hotel was fully booked that night, the problem was, there was not enough hot water. And that is the only thing I would complain. Water from the shower head was not strong and water wasn't even warm... I managed to finish my shower. When it was my boyfriend's turn, hot water was all gone, we called the front desk and ask for help. They allowed him to shower @ the Spa with no charge. Surpringsly, Spa has "unlimited" hot water for him to enjoy! and he also used the sauna. His experience was "OK". Staff were all very friendly, except for one lady. They all put on a smile and tried their best to make you happy. Neighbourhood was good. Felt very safe @ late night. I am a Chinese and love Japanese food, the area has a lot of choices! Overall, this is a good hotel, and I would consider going back if I win this thru priceline again.

Reviews.Title: “Nice place to stay. friendly and clean.”
Reviews.Author: pearlroad
Reviews.Content: Stayed there in a king size single room 1001. Top floor in the corner. Never heard a peep from anyone. Nice size, clean bathroom. The tv channel selections were the only downfall but hopefully you are not there for that. DVD player was also included. Attentive staff. Good room service. Across the street to a line of great asian restaurants.

Reviews.Title: “Fantastic Room Facilities, Economic Stay!”
Reviews.Author: bearsticky
Reviews.Content: Stayed here with my partner and 10yr old daughter during our one month Xmas holidays in US. Got the room thru Priceline.com at $80 per nite. We were Malaysian Chinese who emigrated to Auckland, NZ, 6 yrs ago and will be relocating to Melbourne, Australia after this US trip.
