Great room with 5-star hotel facilities, e.g. free broadband connection, downloaded so many movies, was awesome, has a safe, 2 dbl beds, quiet, coffee making, tv, all that a traveller basically needs. Not much variety in terms of restaurant but found a great takeaway selling grilled chicken lunch/dinners close by. Whole meal cost 3 of us only USD 15.00! Much cheaper by Melbourne standards. Room and furniture dated, but very comfortable beds, after all, when you are touring, hotel rooms are only good for sleeping, not showing off to relatives or friends, as would your home. Parking next door at USD10 per day aft 4pm, some parking close by at USD 4 flat rate but 5 mins walk. Have to be careful if walking back to hotel after dark as lots of homeless people and sleazy areas close by e.g. 3rd St, 5th St, etc. Very scary on some of these streets. My younger bro who visited LA 10yrs back, driving thru Financial District, was held at gun point by a homeless person asking him to hand over his money! My daughter had a huge and frightening cultural shock walking these streets as the bell boy made a big mistake asking us to walk and catch the local bus from these streets! My daughter queried why do we visit USA when it is such an unsafe country! (Makes one appreciate Auckland and Melbourne more) But now that you have the advantage of reading my review and as long as you don't wander off needlessly and take a cab or rent a car whenever you can (get one with GPS), you will be fine. Of course, nothing beats staying at Beverley Hills, etc. but the price you pay there is triple.

Reviews.Title: “Bargain with a great neighborhood feel”
Reviews.Author: techconfgoer
Reviews.Content: Outwardly, the New Miyako has a strong 80s aesthetic. Inside, the rooms are really clean and comfortable. There was even a bidet and a warmed toilet seat - very Japanese! I came for a Msft show at the LA Convention Center. While it is a bit far too walk, you can easily drive and park there. The fact that your hotel will be much cheaper than something nearby - I paid $109 a nite, during a huge convention, mind you - shows you how much you'll probably save. Also, the hotel is in the midst of Japantown and sandwiched by a gentrifying loft area to the east and a trendy club area rising to the west nearer to downtown. So it's a great location, and very safe. The Japanese ramen place across the street, Daikokuya, is a Mecca for Asian noodle lovers. You'll probably get a ticket for a complimentary continental breakfast at the downstairs cafe, Take 5. Take advantage - while it's a bit carb heavy for my taste (croissant etc.) in the morning, the coffee, filtered using some exotic Japanese technology that leaves fine little bubbles, was delicious.

Reviews.Title: “Great Location”
Reviews.Author: N_and_R
Reviews.Content: I went to Los Angeles for a work-related conference, which was held at the convention center. I am not a big fan of the neighborhood around the LA convention center because there's really a lack of a neighborhood feel around it. Also, there is a lack of reasonable food options around the convention center. Instead of staying too far from the convention center, we decided to stay in Little Tokyo, which is relatively close to the convention center. Being a big fan of Japanese food and culture, it was a perfect solution to our problem. The hotel itself, however, was not as nice as I hoped. Basically, we got what we paid for. Our room was clean and relatively functional, but was very small. No special amenities. The doornob, I think, was in need of repair. However, free internet access was great. We had a great government rate deal (I workk for a public benefit corporation for the state of New York) which included a room, free internet, free "continental" breakfast, and a visit to their spa. However, by no means we felt "unsafe." In terms of safety, I would feel much less safe around the convention center. If this hotel was located in a boring neighborhood, I would never recommend this hotel to anyone. However, for those who will be going to LA for a convention, I highly recommend staying at Miyako instead of any of the typical "convention hotels." The hotel is centrally located in Little Tokyo, more centrally so than other hotels. We found too many wonderful places to shop and eat around the hotel than any other hotel we have ever stayed in our travels. We had breakfast mainly in their "Take 5" lobby cafe, but we tried the Japanese style buffet breakfast in their 2nd floor "Tamon" restaurant twice. The breakfast was pretty good, since it was either part of the package at "Take 5" or discounted at "Tamon." However, I think it is sort of silly to stay in the hotel for your food, since there are a lot of options just outside the hotel. Also, the hotel is very close to a couple of museums (Japanese American National Museum and MOCA Geffen), both of them are worth visiting. The spa area on the third floor is clean and nice, probably not the nicest spa I have been to. I may not recommend it unless it is "free." There is a coin operated laundry area, also on the third floor. In summary, I highly recommend this hotel to anyone who needs to stay in downtown LA, especially for conventions. What Little Tokyo offers more than makes up for a old and tired look of the hotel, as well as their quirky customer service. However, if you have no interest in Japanse food and culture, this location is probably not recommended.

Reviews.Title: “Some Good, Some Not-So-Good”
Reviews.Author: leclaire68
Reviews.Content: The Miyako wouldn't have been my first choice of places to book ... but the rate was good and I'm always interested in trying new places. In some places you can find it rated 3-stars, other places 2-stars. In my opinion, it is much closer to a 2-star property. The lobby is nice, valet parking was efficient, and the in-hotel spa ($20 for guests) was decent. The rooms, though, reminded me a bit of a tired low-quality chain hotel. The windows are small (I had a view of the parking structure behind the hotel), the carpets were a tad stained and dusty in the corners, and the sink in the bathroom was chipped. The tub's grout was stained and chunks were missing, too. It wasn't anything that made my stay horrible or anything, but it did let me clearly know that I was not in a true 3-star property. On a side note, the bathroom was equipped with a Japanese bidet and heated toilet seat system. Interesting! The one big gripe I had was the bed. The bedding was fine, but the mattress was provided by Lucifer himself, I'm sure. I felt every spring, especially those the lined up oh-so-perfectly with my rib cage. Since one books a hotel to sleep, I found the bed to be quite a disappointment. On the whole, the Miyako could be a much better hotel with a small to medium sized infusion of cash. Right now, it just comes off as a cheap imitation and not a place to call "home" for very long.

Reviews.Title: “Good for going cheap and 10x better than Motel6”
Reviews.Author: California_Wine
Reviews.Content: Went for a business trip to downtown Los Angeles, and didn't want to spend a lot. The hotel is actually located in a good spot because the Japanese outdoor mall area is next door. All the shops and restaurants you need if you like Japanese food. Across the street too. All are cheap and good. Back in August 2006 the hotel had paid parking from the garage behind it, and I actually could see my car from the room so that was good. Area seemed safe, and didn't see any bums. Mostly tourists. The rooms are as advertised, comfortable and clean, but the wi-fi doesn't work past the fourth floor or something. You'll have to come down to the lobby to check email on your laptop. Considering what other hotels are charging, and their sorry locations, this one is a good deal.

Reviews.Title: “Tries to punch above its weight - not a 3*”
Reviews.Author: Maxing-n-Relaxing
Reviews.Content: I stayed a couple of nights at the Miyako. The lobby is the nicest part of the hotel, if only because of the marble floor and sliding glass doors. The rooms are spartan and a bit dated, basically a bit less nice than a Holiday Inn Express or Howard Johnson. Apparently you can pay extra for a better furnished room - but why not just stay at a nicer hotel if you want to pay more. The room was clean and a reasonable size. In the bathroom the shower head was at an unreasonably low height (this is a Japanese hotel). In terms of facilities, the "coffee shop" is crammed into one corner of the lobby and the "shop" is in another. The "business centre" is a small room (I hesitate to say broom cupboard) off to the side. There is no swimming pool and the "spa" facilties cost extra (one reason I think this hotel is not a 3*, which some travel websites list it as). I found the staff a bit mixed. One front desk agent was overall polite but a little surly, but two other ladies were very polite. The big plus point from my point of view was free overnight parking on the street right outside. You have to circle the block a couple of times to get a space, but it saves on the $18 the hotel charges. Overall this isn't a bad hotel, there are just nicer places to stay.

Reviews.Title: “No sleep hotel!”
Reviews.Author: NEWYORK1961
Reviews.Content: In town for business,booked for 3 nights close to my! meeting,rooms are ok!but if you want to get a goodnite of sleep avoid this place because on 3rd floor there is a karoke bar/OJAH BAR thats open allnite,you hear the loud noise allover the hotel,i spoke to the gm he told me that's how it is!very rude!so i checked after i nite!

Reviews.Title: “Not bad for lone female traveller.”
Reviews.Author: WonderSAdven
Reviews.Content: This hotel was not bad for the money. The room was clean and the staff was friendly. I was a young female staying alone for business and I didn't feel unsafe. The worst thing was the rooms were not very well lit and upon entering the lobby it smelled horribbly like fish. However, the rooms did not smell. The staff was quite friendly but there was a bit of a language barrier. They had many papmplets available at the desk for tourist attractions in the area. Free parkng and close to major freeways. Overall, I would stay in the hotel again. The other hotels in the area were much more expensive in comparision.

Reviews.Title: “Japanese Elegance at the Miyako”
Reviews.Author: Scubatripper
Reviews.Content: What an incredible find. Located in LA's Little Tokyo, the Miyako is an oasis with elegantly appointed rooms done in simple Japanese decor. The rooms were good sized and the bathrooms were large with high-tech toilets that do everything but...... Just think toilet/bidet and massage in one. Even though it's downtown, the neighborhood seemed very nice and friendly, even at midnight. There's a dozen Japanese restaurants right across the street and a small inner city mall nearby. The staff was at the least, prompt and efficient and at best, very friendly. My only caveat would be the plasma screen TVs. You say plasma screen and you think high end. But I've noticed at many hotels with plasma TVs that the screens just aren't very good: blurry, poor resolution and pixelation. But it certainly makes a good impression when you walk in the room. I usually stay in West Hollywood, but on a budget. The price, $115, with free broadband and convenience of the Miyako will be hard to beat.

Reviews.Title: “If you're in that area, it's THE place”
Reviews.Author: museum8888
Reviews.Content: If you need or want to stay downtown and near Little Tokyo, you can't beat it. I had business meetings very nearby, so it was the logical choice for me (since I didn't want to bother with a car), but I was ultimately impressed by the room and staff. I booked through an online room broker and when I called the day before my arrival to confirm the reservation, the hotel staff had no information--yet. (The broker ended up not faxing my reservation until the day of arrival.) In any case, during the phone calls before the reservation came through--when I was a nervous wreck--the front desk staff was unfailingly polite and also advised me on how to resolve the issue. The common areas of the hotel are very clean, and my room was spotless. There were small nicks in the furniture, and this is clearly not a new hotel, but the room was spacious and well-appointed. The snack bar in the lobby had quite a selection of drinks, sandwiches and snacks and is open long hours, and there are some fun sushi shops right around the corner. It's kind of a scruffy neighborhood, but I did not feel unsafe. The rates are also extremely reasonable.

Reviews.Title: “great location”
Reviews.Author: Leesw8
Reviews.Content: Pleasantly surprised by the hotel - ideal for downtown, and despite the other reviews, we felt very safe in the area. We did use the valet parking option at $16 per night. Rooms were basic and fine. Breakfast was included with the AAA rate, which was not great and we did not have it everyday - it was served at a sort of cafe in the lobby.

Reviews.Title: “Ridiculous Parking and not safe location”
Reviews.Author: Anna1201
Reviews.Content: I travel all the time and this was the worst experience I have had regarding service. The hotel itself is nice and cute with good rooms. My problem is the location........freaking scary. The only "safe" area is standing in front of the hotel and the few restaurants across the street. If you walk around the block it is covered with homeless people and not safe at all. Also the parking is a freaking joke. If you don't get your tickets validated every time, you can't leave the garage. I asked if they can call the hotel and verify my room, they said no. I even had a sheet that the hotel asked me to fill out stating I was paying the daily rate of $14 and she the parking attendent said no. I had to go back to my room, go down to the lobby, get my ticket validated then get out of the garage. By the way, the garage is NOT connected, you have to walk in a narrow corridor to get to it through a dark passageway. Are you kidding me????? I will never ever stay here again. I even spoke to the manager about it, and they said that's just how it is. I should be able to put a flyer on my vehicle to show that I piad for parking and just have the attendent open the gate, just like many other hotels do. About the rooms, the bed is a rock, but I liked it.

Reviews.Title: “Not fancy, but clean and quiet”
Reviews.Author: AZ-Dude
Reviews.Content: I stayed at the Miyako the weekend of Feb. 16-18, 2007. I booked my room through Orbitz, which was a mistake, as they charged me for an upgrade room which was not available through Orbitz, but I finally talked the hotel into giving me the room I wanted (Tokyo King). If you want to stay here DO NOT BOOK THROUGH ORBITZ (aka Cheap Tickets)! The hotel itself is nice in a minimalist way. My room was very clean, and the staff was pleasant. There are no on-site dining facilities except for a coffee shop in the lobby, and the Miyako is not convenient to most of LA's better restaurants. There are numerous quick dining places in nearby Little Tokyo, however, so at least you won't starve. I took a shuttle in from LAX, which cost $16. When I was ready to leave, I asked the hotel to get me a seat on a shuttle bus back to the airport. Unfortunately, if you need this service you must make your request the day BEFORE. If you don't, a cab ride to the airport costs $42. Overall, the Miyako is a decent mid-priced hotel that's fairly close to downtown LA. I may stay there again.

Reviews.Title: “Heart of Little Tokyo-Close to Amtrak Station”
Reviews.Author: LaubsMom
Reviews.Content: My husband and I recently did some traveling via Amtrak. We had an overnight stay in Los Angeles so I chose a Hotel that would be close to the Amtrak station. The Miyako is in Little Tokyo, I did realize this when I made the reservations but didn't realize what the situation would be. Much of the information in the room was in Japanese so I couldn't read about anything that the Hotel had to offer. We arrived rather late in the evening. The hotel lobby was a little scary to me at first and I was really worried that I had made reservations to stay there. Our room was ok, nothing special. I really did enjoy the linens on the beds though. They also had down comforters, something you don't find in a lot of hotels these days. They do charge for phone calls, even when you have a calling card. I had to get the front desk to allow my call by giving my credit card number to them once again. Most Hotels where I have stayed do not charge for calling card calls. It wasn't a big deal just somewhat of an inconvenience. The following morning I made a trip to the lobby and was surprised by the difference from the night before. They have a gift shop and a small cafe that was opened and it really helped brighten up the look of the lobby. I had hoped to check out some nearby restaurants while we were there since we had time before we needed to catch the train but my husband wasn't that comfortable so we just headed back to Union Station.

Reviews.Title: “What a nice surprise! Would stay again...”
Reviews.Author: gottagosomewhere
Reviews.Content: I was very surprised of the value and quality of this hotel for a regular room. For the same price elsewhere, for example in or near Hollywood, I would have not been able to get such a nice and quiet room. I would stay at this hotel again. Good: +Quiet and clean room +Reasonably priced +Room is great for singles, couples, etc +Wireless +Nice white duvet with down comforter +Subway station: 4.5 blocks to Civic Center Subway Station (can get to Hollywood/Universal in 20mins) +Close to financial districtâ€”can walk or take modern city shuttles for 25 cents +Unique area-Little Tokyo +Coffee shop within 1.5 blocks-Starbucks (at New Otani Hotel) +Japanese supermarkets nearby offering snacks, bottled water, alcohol and other foods +Staff were friendly and helpful +Nice lobby and corridors +Airport Flyaway Bus to/from Union Station for $3 (Union is one stop from Civic Center Station or you can walk from the hotel in approx. 15 minutes. There is also a metro bus that can be taken close to the hotel that goes to Union station for $1.25) Poor: -Shower was not of hotel standard, although the rest of the washroom was fine. Later I didn't worry much about the shower-wasn't such a big problem. -Lack of restaurants except for Japanese ( but this is understandable for the area being Little Tokyo. Some of these restaurants were only so-so. Other notes: Some travelers mentioned about the homeless in the area. I did see about 4 a day walking by but they kept to themselves. Basically, the area is not that bad at all but I imagine the further east you go, for example East 4th street and San Pedro, it may be a different story yet there is really no need to go to that area. The funny thing is even in Beverly Hills I saw a homeless man, so go figure. Also, I read from others that the beds are very firm. The truth is that theyâ€™re a little on the firm side but not as much as one would think by reading these posts. Itâ€™s definitely true for your back to sleep on more of a firm bed than an overly soft one. And, I actually did sleep very well. No problems at all with this.

Reviews.Title: “Fine hotel for downtown tourist”
Reviews.Author: lite2shine
Reviews.Content: I stayed here during Veterans weekend. I wanted to attend the Japanese American Natural History Museum across from the hotel, so I wanted to stay here so that we don't need to drive a short distance if we stayed other hotels in downtown. The lobby area is small as well as the hotel room (I stayed at a standard room) but it was clean and fine. I don't think their restaurant or breakfast was great for the price but don't eat at the hotel as there are many restaurants in Little Tokyo just around the corner. Caution: the area around the hotel isn't that bad, but you don't want to go down the 3rd street/olive. I forgot to turn on Olive and suddenly I was driving in a skid row.

Reviews.Title: “Great Hotel Comfortable Stay Friendly and Helpful Staff”
Reviews.Author: OriginalGtoBill
Reviews.Content: I read reviews of this hotel while searching for a place to stay. The 'negs' put me off. Then I went to Priceline and what did I get? Miyako Hotel. We arrived around 8pm dreading the no non-smoking rooms if late checkin - What were we met with? Pleasant, cheerful and helpful staff from the car valet, to the concierge and to the desk man. I handed over my Priceline reservation - asked for a non-smoking room and off we were. Nice room - standard layout but with good lighting fixtures, comfy beds- the window even opens. The reason I write tonight is to counter the negs I read earlier: This is a clean and professionally run hotel. Its LA and there have always been interesting street people around. The few street folk we did encounter [only 1 near the Miyako] where actually polite and could be buzzed of easy if that was what you felt like doing.] There is not a liquor or beer store on the block. Litte Tokyo is a nice block and if you walk a bit [go to right exiting hotel] you enter a 'Japanese' street ' actually part of the mall/office complex which makes Little Tokyo all the larger. Another minute down the street a nice Cuban restaurant and next door to it a tendy micro brewery. This is a GOOD location. From my 2 day experience with this hotel I cannot say anything negative [ there was an impending water shutdown - announced 2 days in advance in various notices and on the -'day of'- notes were slipped under every door advising of this '5 to 15 minute inconvenience' This is a professionally run hotel with a wonderful 100% pleasant and helpful staff. Good location - I would not hesitate to book there again.

Reviews.Title: “Room with a 10th Floor View”
Reviews.Author: RoadWarriorChris
Reviews.Content: Well, I don't know what's going on on floors 1 through 9, or really, what's up with all the vitriol of some of the other reviewers, but up here on 10, I have a view of the mountains, a very comfy bed (a strong contender to all the biz chains' bedhead/heavenly etc. offerings), well-appointed surroundings, cool mini-soap to add to my collection (may I never purchase toiletries again!) and a Buddhist text in addition to your ubiquitous Gideon's Bible. Daddy like. I can't imagine bedbugs in this room. Look -- I upgraded (from the standard room booked through PL immediately upon checking-in) based on previous reviews, but honestly, I can't imagine a tiered level of service/accommodation here that could be that extreme. The obligatory list of cons (on the business tip): 1) No available outlets near the work desk. 2) When I'm done working, why can't I ever (in the Miyako, the Hilton, or the Hyatt) watch the few shows I enjoy on TV? It's 2006 -- why am I still limited to Discovery, Oprah and HBO? Sorry, that's an ongoing gripe. Death to OnCommand. That's it. I usually have a few more. Bottom line: This hotel's average review is erroneously slated way too far towards the negative. I would definitely stay here again.

Reviews.Title: “ok hotel”
Reviews.Author: yukoy
Reviews.Content: Stayed 2 nights in July '06. Ok for $89/night. Free fridge in the room was great. Room was fine too. Only thing was the water. It smelled like sewage water. I made coffee with this water and tasted bad too. When I made coffee with same coffee packet at Hotel Otani a couple days later it was fine so it must have been the water at Miyako. Has free high speed internet. Good for the price if you can book it for less than $100/night. If not, Otani is better.

Reviews.Title: “Bad faith. Won't stay again.”
Reviews.Author: visitor1095
Reviews.Content: Booked room through PLine. Asked for non-smoking. Gave me smoking, smelly room overlooking busy street. Blamed this on late booking. I believe this was not because the non-smoking rooms were booked, as the hotel seems uncrowded and not busy, but because of the priceline booking. Poor location of self park in public lot distant from rooms, elevator. Room in bad shape. Cigarette burns in table. Stained chairs. Bathroom in bad shape, cracked tile, cracked sink. Someday, someone will file a class action against priceline/these hotels which typcially do not provide the three or four star class advertised by priceline. Further, priceline does not notify purchasers that parking is not free.

Reviews.Title: “Great Place!!”
Reviews.Author: segraybill
Reviews.Content: I was pretty nervous after reading some of the reviews, but the room turned out to be great!!! The staff was very helpful from the moment we walked in until we checked out. The room was very nice and the bed with the thick comforter was very comphy. I would definately stay there again!!!

Reviews.Title: “Enjoyed my stay very much”
Reviews.Author: alertvideo
Reviews.Content: Stayed 5 nights at the Miyako a couple of weeks ago and enjoyed it. All things considered it compared favorably (minus the restaurants) to my stay at the Westin Bonaventure in late June. It IS in Little Tokyo and definitely has a Japanese feel to it - I don't understand why this surprises people. My room was above average and comfortable. The efficient and friendly staff made my stay a good one and I would stay there again.

Reviews.Title: “make sure you get a nonsmoking room”
Reviews.Author: allady
Reviews.Content: I got this room through Expedia, asked for a non smoking room. Arrived and there were no nonsmoking rooms available, except for $40.00 more. We visited the smoking room, which was on the smoking floor and didn't make it more than 2 steps into the room, before we were overcome by the smell. Take a Vegas casino and multiply it by 10,000 and you have the level of stench. Never have I encountered a worse smell. It would have been unbreathable, so we couldn't stay there. The hotel would not cancel the reservation or refund the money, but Expedia made good on the deal. No monetary loss, but it was 4pm and we had no room. We stayed at the Days Inn, cheaper, bigger room, great bathroom, smokefree, free breakfast, friendly, helpful people and $4.00 a day parking. You do the math.

Reviews.Title: “Glorified Motel 6!!”
Reviews.Author: littlejoy
Reviews.Content: We stayed at the Miyako for just one night, which is good, because that is all I could handle! We got a cheap price on Priceline, thank goodness, as I would never pay full price for this hotel. I would be extremely upset if we had to pay more than our $50 on priceline. Our standard room was very plain, no decor on walls, just the headboards. I did check for bedbugs, but all seemed ok there-Shower heads are made for people on the shorter side, and bathrooms needed to be upgraded a bit. Peeling wallpaper, chipped paint in sink, and faucets didnt work too well. Could hear neighbors every time they took a shower or flushed toilet.The valet parking fee was high, $15, but so is all the parking in downtown LA, so I was expecting it. The one thing I did like was that the rooms had a DVD player, which was great for my 3 yr old. Staff was pretty friendly, the bellhop guy, who took our luggage up to our room, was extremely friendly, and even made us a map, with good,local sushi resteraunts. I wouldnt want to stay here again, but if you are looking for a decent room with just a place to lay your head, this will suffice.

HotelInfo.Name: Miyako Hotel Los Angeles
HotelInfo.Address: 328 East First Street, Los Angeles, CA 90012-3902
